question_text: If opposite poles attract, why does the North side of a compass point north instead of south?
answer1: The reason that the north side of a compass points north instead of south is because opposite poles attract each other. The north pole of the compass is attracted to the south pole of the earth, and vice versa. This interaction between the poles is what causes the compass needle to point in a particular direction.
answer2: The opposite electrical charges attract. There's nothing that actually matters about how we label them as North and South. For a compass, we've made it so the side that points to the magnetic north pole is labeled as North.
comments:
As per answer B, the word opposite electrical charges may seem vague. Why because, in fact the opposite poles North and South are in fact magnetic poles. However answer A is clear in this regard. In defining magnetic poles of the Earth, the Earth's south magnetic pole is near Earth's geographic north. Earth's magnetic north pole is near Earth's geographic south. That's why the north pole of a compass points toward north because that's where Earth's south magnetic pole is located and they attract. This is brought about in answer A.
 That is to be further clarified as follows.  In fact magnetic  compass does not point to the geographic north pole. Essentially,  a magnetic compass points to the earth's magnetic poles, which are not the same as earth's geographic poles. Furthermore, the magnetic pole near earth's geographic north pole is actually the south magnetic pole. When it comes to magnets, opposites attract.  As per answer A, "The north pole of the compass is attracted to the south pole of the earth, and vice versa. This interaction between the poles is what causes the compass needle to point in a particular direction." it is clearly indicated.
This fact means that the north end of a magnet in a compass is attracted to the south magnetic pole, which lies close to the geographic north pole. Hypothetically, the magnetic field lines exit from the magnetic North pole and enters from the South magnetic pole.  This is further explained in the website "https://www.acs.org/content/dam/acsorg/education/resources/k-8/science 
activities/characteristicsofmaterials/magnetsmetals/magnets-point-the-way-science-for-kids.pdf". It explains that, "Earth's south magnetic pole is near Earth's geographic north. Earth's magnetic north pole is near Earth's geographic south. That's why the north pole of a compass points toward north because that's where Earth's south magnetic pole is located and they attract."
So it is not difficult to be separated between two answers A and B

question_text: Why can’t we just build more nuclear power stations to reduce carbon emissions?
answer1: There are several reasons why we can't just build more nuclear power stations to reduce carbon emissions. First, nuclear power is expensive to build and maintain. Second, nuclear power plants produce radioactive waste that is difficult to dispose of safely. Finally, nuclear power plants can be potential targets for terrorist attacks.
answer2: Easy enough to do.  Nuclear has an image problem, though.  People don't like them and don't want them around, so permitting is a nightmare.  California just shut down its last nuclear plant, in fact.
comments:
Answer A provides reasons one by one. In fact it gives three reasons and answer B fails to provide more. As answer A suggests there are pros and cons of implementing nuclear power. It has advantages over other power sources in terms of carbon emissions. However nuclear power plants pose several threats in terms of implementation. As answer A suggests Nuclear power plants have an instinct disadvantage of producing radioactive leakages. These leakages can be harmful to human beings so generally the plants are located in remote locations from human habitat, Further to answer A, Secondly, there is also a challenge in terms of disposing radioactive material. These radioactive material residues have to be dumped securely without harming the environment. Otherwise it can pollute the environment and can be a source of pollution. In terms of nuclear energy, the cost of energy in terms of units and running cost is less. Nevertheless cost of implementation is too high.
Since, answer A is straight on this fact, Answer A is selected over answer B

question_text: If atoms never touch each other then how does sound travel between them? There can’t be sounds in space because of the vacuum (no matter). How does sound travel between atoms if they never touch each other? Isn’t there nothing in between the atoms?
answer1: There are *forces* between atoms. However it’s extremely difficult to intuitively grasp or explain these forces because they don’t resemble anything else with which we are familiar. <newline>Here’s Nobel Prize-winning physicist Richard Feynman explaining why you can’t really explain such forces to a five year old, or even to an intelligent adult who is not a physicist:<newline>https://youtu.be/MO0r930Sn_8
answer2: They do push against each other without touching. Like how the same poles of two magnets push against each other without touching. Does that help?
comments:
Answer A fails to bring out the explanation. Answer B seems to attempt to speak to the point. But there are deficiencies in answer B also. This is my account to support answer B further. Actually, there will be molecular interaction without touching each other. It is simple to visualize example of air. How sound waves are propagated through air will be an ideal example to visualize how sound waves are propagated through a medium, without atoms being in contact. Actually when sound waves are generated there are compressions and rarefactions that propagate the sound waves through a particular medium. So it is not merely atom to atom, but rather a collection of atoms. Atoms collectively in collaboration produce a region where there is a compression and a rarefaction. In that way, there will be transfer of sound energy. Similarly in other mediums too there will be relative movement of molecule rather than the atom itself.
Actually there will be an electron cloud surrounding an atom too. That will basically behave as an electron cloud. Answer A doesn't provide a comprehensive explanation neither the answer B. But however, given that answer B gives the correct direction for the solution Answer B is chosen to be the better choice.

question_text: Where is the universe expanding to? I know this has already been asked, but how /where is it expanding? If the end of the universe is the end of everything, then how is it getting bigger? What is the area outside of the universe that is being taken over as the universe expands?
answer1: There is no agreed-upon answer to this question since there is no agreed-upon model of the universe. Some scientists believe that the universe is infinite and so it is not expanding into anything, while others believe that it is expanding into a higher dimensional space. Some scientists also believe that the universe will eventually stop expanding and start contracting again. There is no definitive answer to this question since there is no definitive model of the universe.
answer2: Nothing.   <newline>Because if there was something, it would be part of the universe.   <newline>When they say the universe is expanding, they mean that everything is getting further apart from each other everywhere. Not that there's a not-universe the universe is displacing.
comments:
As answer A suggests, and according to website, "https://www.discovery.com/science/what-are-the-chances-of-life-appearing-on-earth-" "The universe is everything, so it isn't expanding into anything. It's just expanding. All of the galaxies in the universe are moving away from each other, and every region of space is being stretched, but there's no center they're expanding from and no outer edge to expand into anything else." Answer B leaves a void by simply giving an answer as nothing. 
Also according to website "https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2021/apr/18/readers-reply-the-universe-is-expanding-but-what-is-it-expanding-into" "To say that “the universe is expanding” because what we can see and observe from our part of it that it looks to be moving away from a certain point sounds to me like hubris."
In terms of answering this is a tricky question, so answer A provides the hypothesis of some scientists in "Some scientists believe that the universe is infinite and so it is not expanding into anything, while others believe that it is expanding into a higher dimensional space. Some scientists also believe that the universe will eventually stop expanding and start contracting again. There is no definitive answer to this question since there is no definitive model of the universe." But in answer B, "When they say the universe is expanding, they mean that everything is getting further apart from each other everywhere. Not that there's a not-universe the universe is displacing." seems like not a concrete evidence.
So answer A is selected over answer B

question_text: If the JWST will observe photons of light coming from the creation of the universe, how are we already so far away from the place where it happened?
answer1: This question is based on a common misconception. The Big Bang didn't happen in a specific location, it happened **everywhere**. The idea though is that all *locations* were much closer together in the early universe so all places had basically no distance from each other. As the universe expanded more distance rapidly came into existence; things weren't flying apart moving *through* space, the *space itself* was getting more distant from other locations.<newline>The universe even when very close and dense was still likely infinite in extent.
answer2: The JWST will observe photons of light coming from the creation of the universe, but we are already far away from the place where it happened. The universe is expanding, and the further away something is from us, the faster it is moving away from us. So, the photons that the JWST will observe are coming from a time when the universe was much smaller and denser than it is now.
comments:
As answer A suggests. and according to website "https://skyandtelescope.org/astronomy-news/cosmology/where-was-the-big-bang-located/#:~:text=Actually%2C%20the%20Big%20Bang%20gave,Bang%20happened%20everywhere%20at%20once." ," Actually, the Big Bang gave birth not just to matter but to space itself. Space then expanded so the matter in space thinned out. In other words, the Big Bang happened right where you're sitting just as much as anywhere. Here's the short, elevator-speech version: The Big Bang happened everywhere at once."
Therefore as answer "A" correctly points out "The Big Bang didn't happen in a specific location, it happened **everywhere**. The idea though is that all *locations* were much closer together in the early universe so all places had basically no distance from each other. As the universe expanded more distance rapidly came into existence; things weren't flying apart moving *through* space, the *space itself* was getting more distant from other locations" . In answer B, "The universe is expanding, and the further away something is from us, the faster it is moving away from us." is not clear too.
In answer B why we are so far away is not explained. Further to the answer A explanation above are evidences to support the same fact. So answer A chosen to have provided a better explanation.

question_text: if theres no gravity in space how do rockets steer/move? Wouldn't it be hard land perpendicular on the moon?
answer1: They use thrusters, which are tiny "rocket engines" (sometimes they just puff gas under pressure) on the sides of the ship.  Gravity actually has little to do with it - it's the lack of air that makes aerodynamic surfaces like ailerons and rudders ineffective.
answer2: Rockets are able to steer and move in space because they rely on the force of their engines to propel them in the desired direction. Without gravity, there is nothing to pull them back down to the surface of a planet or moon, so they can continue moving in a straight line indefinitely. This can make landing on a planet or moon tricky, as it can be difficult to judge the correct angle and approach needed to land perpendicular on the surface.
comments:
As answer B suggests, Rockets function as non air breathing engines. https://www.mpoweruk.com/rockets.htm
That is to say, the rockets do not take air from the atmosphere, rather they carry Oxygen inside tanks in the rocket itself. Further, the rockets carry fuel and combust them inside and propel through the thrusters. https://science.howstuffworks.com/rocket.htm
By changing the direction of the thrusters, according to the conservation of momentum there will be a transfer of momentum from fuel to the rocket. https://study.com/academy/lesson/rocket-propulsion-definition-principles.html
But in answer A the operation rocket engines is not elaborated. As it is explained in answer B, However, it will be difficult to maneuver the rocket on to the surface of the moon in the perpendicular landing. It has to be carefully done. Answer A also fails to explain the second part of the question too.  where as answer B gives overall account for all the parts requested by the question. So preference choice is answer B

question_text: why does water spill when first poured from full pitchers/carafes? I was pouring my coffee today, and when the carafe is full, the coffee has a tendency to spill or dribble down the outside of the carafe. This isn't an issue when the carafe is less full.
answer1: Roughly speaking, water doesn't like air, but does like glass (and some other things).<newline>So as you tip things the water clings to the glass so it touches as little air as possible and as much glass as possible.<newline>But once it gets flowing there is enough of a push to break that.
answer2: There are a few reasons why water spills when first poured from full pitchers or carafes. One reason is that when the pitcher or carafe is full, the weight of the water can cause the spout to open slightly, which allows water to drip or spill out. Another reason is that when the container is full, the water level is higher than the spout, so the water has to travel further to reach the spout, which can cause it to spill or dribble out. Finally, when the container is full, the water is also under more pressure, which can cause it to spill or dribble out if the spout is not opened wide enough.
comments:
According to answer A, actually, this has something to do with the "like" molecules and the surface tension of water. When water is poured out from a full pitcher/carafe, then water tends to cling on to the solid. This is highlighted in answer A in simple day to day words. But we know that surface tension forces are weaker molecular bonds. Once water starts to pour out or when liquid is starting to flow faster, there is no more tendency for these molecules to cling on to. Therefore, overcoming these weaker molecular attraction forces, liquid tend to pour rather than dribbling or dripping along the surface.  With respect to the explanation without using many technical terms, Answer A has produced a better explanation compared to Answer B and answer B also seems a bit distracted.
What actually expressed in answer B "One reason is that when the pitcher or carafe is full, the weight of the water can cause the spout to open slightly, which allows water to drip or spill out" is not actually clear.
So the real explanation is more closer in answer A than answer B, thus answer A is selected to be the better one.

question_text: Why when holding a magnifying glass in a certain angle on a sunny day causes things like wood and cotton to burn?
answer1: Sunlight carries with it energy. About a thousand watts per square meter on a good day. A 6-cm magnifying glass takes up about 0.28% of a square meter, so it will be collecting around 2.8 watts of power - that's about a fifth of a small candle. It is concentrated down to a very small area - smaller than a candle flame, and so as far as that small area is concerned, it may as well be held over a flame.
answer2: A magnifying glass works by gathering the light from a larger area and focussing it into a smaller area. When using a magnifying glass normally, you're taking the light bouncing off the thing you're looking at and focussing it into your eye-hole.<newline>If you bring a magnifying glass outside on a sunny day, [this happens](https://i.imgur.com/sJxraPg.png). All the sunlight (and heat energy) that hits the whole large surface of the magnifying glass gets focused and concentrated to be hitting a MUCH smaller point. So like, if you focus the power onto a spot 1/100th the size of the glass itself, that spot gets 100x more heat on it than just being in normal sunlight. Also notice you're not creating energy here. The hot spot gets a shadow around it. You're just moving and gathering most of the light that would have hit the circle and redistributing it into a much smaller spot and leaving a shadow around that spot.
comments: Magnifying glass is a convex lens as the answer B suggests. Answer A brings in information relevant to the  same fact quantitatively.. So it is capable of concentrating electromagnetic waves, which are in the form of light and thermal radiation. This concentrated light especially the thermal energy is capable of igniting wood and cotton. Further according to answer B, this is simply because of the thermal energy concentrated by the magnifying glass. This is according to the refraction principle of light waves. However, actually what happens is sunlight incident on the larger area of the magnifying glass is concentrated in to much smaller area called the focal point. Answer B explains this in simple words. It also brings out to the limelight that glass itself is not basically generating heat but a concentrator. So Answer B gives a better explanation overall. Answer A also compares areas accurately which is factually correct " A 6-cm magnifying glass takes up about 0.28% of a square meter." Quantitative approach can be seen in answer A, but answer B has provided a better overall explanation in simple terms.

question_text: what causes race cars to sometimes spin out when taking a turn? The only understanding I have is that applying too much throttle can be attributed to this, but how does increasing acceleration lead to a loss of control?
answer1: So many things, surface condition, oversteer, understeer, condition of the tyres, cornering speed - bear in mind race cars usually operating on the very edge of grip - with the downforce they provide, so any marginal thing will likely cause it to “snap” and spin
answer2: It depends on the type of car why they spun. Front wheel drive cars spin when you close the throttle mid turn. Rear wheel drive cars spin when you go too fast into it or accelerate too soon and all wheel drive cars do both but less often.
comments:
As per answer A, Spinning of racing cars on a turn is mainly due to the loss of traction force on the surface of the race track." Answer B compares the cars between front wheel and rear wheel cars. But Answer A compares all the factors that can lead to this scenario.
According to answer A, Actually, in a turn, a car negotiates a circular path. When a vehicle is in circular motion, there should be certain parameters that should be conducive, in order to have described a proper circular path. For an example, there should be sufficient force acting towards the center when the car is in a turn, if there is not enough force towards the center car would either slip or skid. If force towards is less then it would tend to slip towards the center. On the contrary, if the car has a greater speed what can be accommodated during a turn,  then the car would tend to skid and jump out of the turn. As such, there is a tendency for the car to lose control if there is a steering input while the car is in a skid or a slip with the combination of brakes. As the answer A explains, there can be more conditions which attribute to this. They can be "surface condition, oversteer, understeer, condition of the tyres, cornering speed". According to "https://www.roadandtrack.com/car-culture/a30913/how-to-not-spin/" there are more conditions given. The provision of the centrifugal force is provided by many factors such as banking or friction force on the race tracks. Conditions of the tyres should also be good in order to prevent spinning of race cars. 
By bringing about all these factors answer A has provided a better answer than answer B

question_text: Why do heavy objects fall at the same speed as light ones? Shouldn't gravity make objects which mass is greater attract each other more and therefore touch each other more quickly? Or maybe the mass of the Earth is so big that the difference between two objects in perspective is negligible, especially on the very short distance between them and the soil? Not sure... could you explain?
answer1: They do attract each other more, heavy objects fall with a greater force than light objects they just fall at the same velocity. The impact of a heavy object when it hits the ground is far greater, but force = mass times acceleration so the greater mass is balanced out by the greater force.
answer2: Physics. Terminal velocity is a thing that matters a lot more than it seems. Also weight/mass while related, are two separate factors out of many factors that affect speed of falling objects. I’m definitely no physics person, but I believe that a heavier object needs more time to get to terminal velocity even though with enough time it will ultimately have a greater pull on it due to being heavier. A smaller object will reach terminal velocity more quickly, but it won’t go as fast. These two things exist on a parabola where there’s a lot of overlap because there’s often not a large enough free fall. Example of physics, an average sized human’s free fall terminal velocity is about 85-90mph, but a streamlined human can get to well over 100, and a human wearing specific clothing/attire can get even faster in a fall. That’s a variance of 60-70mph ultimately in an object that’s the same mass/size/relatively same shape just oriented differently or otherwise affecting drag.
comments: As per answer A,  when the mass of an object increases, there is a difference between the gravitational attraction. But since the height from which the object is falling compared to the mass of the Earth is negligible. So it doesn't make much of a difference. In order this gravitational force to experience a big difference, the height that we consider should be greater. However as mentioned in Answer B it will make a comparatively big difference if we consider the drag force due to air resistance. If the mass of an object is greater, then the air resistance encountered is greater by the heavier object. If the mass of an object is lesser, then the air resistance by the lighter mass is lesser. As answer B suggests "Terminal velocity is a thing that matters a lot more than it seems. Also weight/mass while related, are two separate factors out of many factors that affect speed of falling objects." terminal velocity is applicable for masses falling under air resistance. Actually as per answer A the factors to be considered are acceleration due to gravity, air resistance and height of falling. Since answer A and B are close calls, in terms of facts answer A is considered to be better.

question_text: how does a nuclear reactor and nuclear energy work? How does a nuclear reactor and nuclear energy work?
answer1: A nuclear reactor uses radioactive materials as their fuel source. A chain reaction is started where neutrons slam into the other atoms which in turn also shoot off neutrons. But these neutrons are flying away at a high rate of speed, and they need to be slowed down a bit to make them more likely to hit another atom; this is where the moderator comes in. There are a few different things that can do this function, even just water.<newline>To control the reaction so they can make it happen more slowly over time instead of releasing all that insane energy at once, things such as control rods (which instead absorb neutrons instead of just slowing them down) are also put in the reactor.<newline>All this neutron whizzing about breaking other atoms like a cue ball on a pool table creates heat, crazy amounts of heat. This is captured via what is called the primary loop, which is water that is being circulated through the reactor both to help keep it cool and to collect that heat. This then goes to an exchanger where the primary water heats up secondary water (you don't want the primary water which is being exposed to neutron radiation to be outside the containment), and this secondary water gets turned into steam. This is what actually drives the steam turbines.<newline>Tldr: Nuclear reactions are atoms losing pieces that bump into other atoms and make them break up too, this makes shitloads of heat. The heat is collected and used for running a steam turbine.
answer2: A nuclear reactor is a device used to initiate and control a nuclear chain reaction. Nuclear reactors are used to generate electricity and to produce plutonium for nuclear weapons. <newline><newline>Nuclear power plants use nuclear fission to generate electricity. In a typical nuclear power plant, uranium fuel is enriched to about 3-5% U-235 and then formed into pellets. These pellets are then placed in fuel rods, which are bundled together to form a fuel assembly. <newline><newline>The fuel assembly is placed in the reactor core, where the nuclear fission reaction takes place. The fission reaction releases heat, which is used to generate steam. The steam turns turbines, which generate electricity. <newline><newline>Nuclear reactors are closely regulated to ensure the safety of the public and the environment. Nuclear power plants must meet strict safety and security regulations.
comments:
As answer A explains " nuclear power plants can be found with radio active materials" They include enriched uranium, low-level waste, and spent nuclear fuel. Enriched uranium is the fuel for nuclear power plants. In a nuclear reaction, two nuclei or one nucleus and another sub atomic particle collide to form one or more nuclides. In nuclear power plants nuclear fission process is explained. In terms of the comprehensive answer to cover all the required ingredients are provided in answer B. Answer A doesn't exclusively discuss about nuclear energy as a whole. Answer A concentrates more on the nuclear reactions rather than nuclear power and energy. Answer B covers both aspects of nuclear power and nuclear energy.
Further adding to Answer B, reactors use uranium for nuclear fuel. The uranium is processed into small ceramic pellets and stacked together into sealed metal tubes called fuel rods. Typically, more than 200 of these rods are bundled together to form a fuel assembly. A reactor core is typically made up of a couple hundred assemblies, depending on power level. (https://www.energy.gov/ne/articles/nuclear-101-how-does-nuclear-reactor-work). Answer B also accounts for how the generation of power is achieved in a nuclear power plant. Considering these aspects answer B is considered to be the better answer.

question_text:
How is energy conserved when two forces counteract? If there are 2 forces on the same object, that counteract, the object doesn't move.
But there was energy released to create these forces. If these forces don't cause anything to move, doesn't it mean that that energy was destroyed?
answer1: Applying perfectly opposite forces in a perfectly static and rigid world - doesn't actually expend any energy. The act of applying a force doesn't expend energy - its the act of applying a force over a distance which does.<newline>In the real world, since everything is elastic, the thing you are compressing/stretching with your forces, plus the structure that the forces are reacting against will act like stiff springs - and this is where the energy gets stored.<newline>For example press your hands together in front of your chest. As you press:<newline>* Some energy gets stored into the squishing of your palms<newline>* Some energy gets stored in the compression of the bones in your forearms<newline>* Some energy gets stored in the tension of your upper arms and the bones across your shoulders<newline>The chances are some energy will be lost to heat, since flesh is unlikely to be a particularly efficient elastic. <newline>Since you don't apply the force over much distance, very little energy is stored. If you put a spring between your hands, now you apply the force over more distance and more energy is stored (which is apparent when you let the spring go!)
answer2: Energy cannot be created or destroyed, only transformed from one type to another. In this case, the energy was converted from potential energy to kinetic energy and then back to potential energy. The object didn't move, so the kinetic energy was quickly converted back to potential energy.
comments:
In this case, there is no energy required as Answer A explains, since there is no movement of the object. "The act of applying a force doesn't expend energy". And further answer A adds that "its the act of applying a force over a distance which does expand energy." Therefore since no work is done since there is no movement of the object. 
Answer B basically, revolves around energy. When it comes to answer A and B in terms of balancing the context of the question, there is solid grounds to provide that answer A has provided a better explanation.
In actual terms, although there is energy being exerted to apply a force, there is no work done since there is no movement. In physics principle there is no energy expelled. This is in accordance with principles of physics. Further there will only be work done if there is movement of an object over a distance and then we can consider that there is certain amount of energy associated with it. 
In overall aspects, answer A provides a better explanation of this particular concept.

question_text: Why can’t we dispose of nuclear waste by shooting it into deep space?
answer1: The main reason why we can't dispose of nuclear waste by shooting it into deep space is because it would be incredibly expensive to do so. Additionally, there is no guarantee that the waste would not eventually come back to Earth, potentially causing harm to our planet and its inhabitants.
answer2: Cost. Currently to get mass into low earth orbit it costs many thousands of dollars per kg. We don't want to fill low earth orbit with waste so really we need it on at least an earth escape trajectory, and ideally a sun escape. This ramps up the cost even more. Storing nuclear waste is a hassle, but it isn't as expensive or dangerous as launching it into space.
comments: This again a close call between answers A and B. As mentioned in answer A, "The main reason why we can't dispose of nuclear waste by shooting it into deep space is because it would be incredibly expensive to do so.". This is again mentioned in answer B. Nuclear waste still has certain amount of radioactivity left in it. Therefore its disposal has to be secured and non harming to the inhabitants. Moreover the process has to be cost effective. In terms of cost incurred in shooting nuclear waste in to sun or space, it is far more costly than that can be afforded. More the weight, higher would be the cost. Therefore it is required to have a mechanism to dump nuclear waste in a manner in which it is not harming to the species. There is an element of danger also associated to it also. Firstly if during launch, there is a misfire or failure there is a risk of falling back to earth. Secondly, during orbiting there can be a hazard of nuclear waste falling back to earth. So considering all those aspects it is not the feasible option. This is mentioned in answer "A". "Additionally, there is no guarantee that the waste would not eventually come back to Earth, potentially causing harm to our planet and its inhabitants.".  Further reasons are mentioned in answer B as "We don't want to fill low earth orbit with waste so really we need it on at least an earth escape trajectory, and ideally a sun escape. This ramps up the cost even more. Storing nuclear waste is a hassle, but it isn't as expensive or dangerous as launching it into space.". Therefore between the two tight calls, between answers A and B, answer B is selected to be the assuming.

question_text: what theories are out there about what came before the Big Bang?
answer1: The current model for what happened before the big bang is known as cosmic inflation.<newline>The basic idea is that the Big Bang on its own explains many of the observations made my scientists regarding the structure of the universe. However, what is interesting is that there are several observations that the Big Bang *cannot* explain, such as:<newline>\- why was the universe "born" perfectly flat?<newline>\- why is the universe the same temperature (up to over 99% accuracy) in all directions when there hasn't been enough time for the temperature of the universe to "even out" all the way?<newline>\- why aren't there various high-energy relics (like magnetic monopoles - a magnet that's only North or South, but *not both*) when the Standard Model (the current frame work of the smallest particles in physics) predicted that such relics should exist as a result of the insanely high energy of the Big Bang?<newline>\- why did the universe begin with such low entropy (which is a measure of "disorder" in a system)? Especially considering the fact that entropy always increases in closed systems?<newline>After the Big Bang model became accepted in the first half of the 1900's, scientists have struggled to answer these questions above according to the framework of the Big Bang.<newline>However, in the '70s and '80s a scientist named Alan Guth came up with a model explains everything the Big Bang did, *and* also explains the unsolved observations not accounted by the Big Bang. This model is known as cosmic inflation, and put simply it is the idea that the energy in the first moments of universe wasn't in particles or radiation, but in the fabric of space itself. So what happened *before* the Big Bang is that the fabric of space itself began to exponentially inflate to an unimaginable degree, and we call the "Big Bang" is actually the end of this inflationary period.<newline>So then that begs the question: what happened before the inflationary period? Sadly, no one knows. It is possible that some kind of singularity existed before inflation. It is also possible that inflation never stopped, which would imply the existence of a multiverse. Or it could be that inflations happen cyclically, which implies an eternal universe.<newline>What's really interesting here is that the scientists who figured out and basically proved that inflation came first did this forty years ago. So anyone who still tries to argue that the Big Bang was the first event in the universe is at least forty years outdated.
answer2: Tesla said there is a primordial soup and we are being churned in it - that would be the big bang, the start of the churn, so the soup would be there but motionless, or the possibility of all motion, however you want to look at it.
comments:
Answer B only considers the Tesla's soup theory. But According to website "https://www.buffalo.edu/news/releases/2022/03/033.html#:~:text=“Inflation%20tells%20us%20that%20the,state%20before%20the%20Big%20Bang.",  "In the beginning, the world was empty and cold. Prior to the Big Bang  yes, before the Big Bang  the universe underwent a breathtaking cosmic expansion, doubling in size at least 80 times in a fraction of a second. This rapid inflation, fueled by a mysterious form of energy that permeated empty space itself, left the universe desolate and cold. Only after that did the hot, dense conditions of the Big Bang emerge: As the doubling of the universe ceased, the energy of the vacuum underwent a metamorphosis, transforming into particles of matter and radiation. That metamorphosis flooded space with the superhot plasma of the Big Bang, which forged the primordial elements that went on to make the stars and galaxies we see today." This is also given in answer A. 
According to website "https://www.bbc.com/future/article/20220105-what-existed-before-the-big-bang", "In the first moments after the Big Bang, the Universe was a hot soup of particles where space and time was still to properly emerge". This is as explained in answer B.
There are several hypotheses. 
According to the website, "https://www.space.com/what-came-before-big-bang.html", "In the beginning, there was an infinitely dense, tiny ball of matter. Then, it all went bang, giving rise to the atoms, molecules, stars and galaxies we see today. Or at least, that's what we've been told by physicists for the past several decades. But new theoretical physics research has recently revealed a possible window into the very early universe, showing that it may not be "very early" after all. Instead it may be just the latest iteration of a bang-bounce cycle that has been going on for … well, at least once, and possibly forever.
Overall these aspects are covered in answer A and it provides a better explanation. Since the question asks about what theories and answer B only narrows down to one theory, answer A is selected to be the better overall answer.

question_text: how does a speaker vibrate at multiple frequencies simultaneously to deliver sounds to our ears? I'll try and explain what I mean.. say a song is playing - how do the vocals, drums, guitars etc which all have different frequencies (aka a plate is moving back & forth at a rate to deliver these sound waves) play at the same time? Surely the plate can't vibrate to deliver two or more frequencies at once?
answer1: This has been asked many times and the answer is they don’t. If you listen to the song being played live on purely acoustic instruments even though they are being played separately and emitting their own frequencies, what you hear (and by extension, what a microphone captures) at any given time is just ONE frequency that’s the “sum” of all the others combined. A speaker is just a reverse microphone.
answer2: Imagine an ocean with a consistent wave. It flows up and down, with equal distance between the two waves at any time.<newline>Now imagine I push a larger, shorter wave into this ocean. The two waves will collide, resulting in some new wave pattern. This new wave pattern is a combination of those two waves.<newline>Speakers work similarly. If I combine two soundwaves, I get a new combination wave that sounds different.
comments:
In technical terms ocean waves stated in answer B are transverse waves and sound waves are longitudinal waves. In comparison answer B mentions about ocean waves and it is different to the sound waves in the question. But apart from that  actually the two answers A and B go very close to each other and they provide similar explanations. But answer A is selected to be slightly better in terms of applicability and relevance. Other than that principle explained in answer B is also applicable. Answer B explains "Now imagine I push a larger, shorter wave into this ocean. The two waves will collide, resulting in some new wave pattern. This new wave pattern is a combination of those two waves. Speakers work similarly. If I combine two soundwaves, I get a new combination wave that sounds different." It actually is the combination of the sound waves that is output by the speaker. In answer A,"  what you hear (and by extension, what a microphone captures) at any given time is just ONE frequency that’s the “sum” of all the others combined. A speaker is just a reverse microphone."
Actually, the speaker's movement changes as the intensity of the sound waves are changed. So it actually outputs a particular frequency. Not many frequencies at the same time. Further, it cannot provide all the frequencies at the same time. So in terms of technical approach and considering overall accuracy answer A is selected.

question_text: How the bodies/remains from 9/11 couldn't be found/are "just gone" from a building collapse?
answer1: The most optimal range of a crematorium oven is 1400-1800 degrees Fahrenheit. Temperatures at ground zero were as high as 1377. So, while not optimal, it can still turn a body into dust over weeks (the fires burned for 100 days).
answer2: There are a number of potential explanations for why the bodies/remains from 9/11 couldn't be found/are "just gone" from a building collapse. One possibility is that the bodies were completely incinerated in the intense heat of the collapse. Another possibility is that the bodies were pulverized by the force of the collapse. Finally, it is also possible that the bodies were buried beneath the rubble and simply couldn't be recovered.
comments:
Answer A in this case doesn't provide how temperature is so great in the 9/11 incidents of the building. Comparatively answer B provides three reasons why it is so. Further, According to the physicists and scientists who attempted to explain the science behind this incident, one of the outstanding and convincing theory was the momentum transfer of aircrafts to the building. It was apparent, even in the visuals the impact of the two aircrafts to the building has transferred huge momentum to the two buildings. Since the kinetic energy possessed by the aircrafts due to hundreds of tons of weight flying at considerable speed  had ultimately transferred to the building in terms of excessive kinetic energy. As a result of which, the kinetic energy had eventually being dissipated in to heat energy which was absorbed by the concrete and metal structure of the building. Due to the heat generated by this kinetic energy transfer and heat dissipated to the structure had resulted in melting of the concrete & metal structure and the building. Therefore, building was collapsed to the ground. Due to the heat generated, impact and demolition of the building to the ground obviously couldn't have safely secured any bodies or remains in tact. According to the website, "https://theconversation.com/9-11-the-controversial-story-of-the-remains-of-the-world-trade-center-167481"Thousands of tonnes of pulverised concrete, construction debris, cellulose, asbestos, lead and mercury, and fire dioxins increased the risk of kidney, heart, liver and breast cancer among first respondents. Over the next decade, surviving first responders filed workers’ compensation claims and sued NYC for failing to provide proper protective equipment at Ground Zero, until the passing of the 9/11 Health and Compensation Act, a law created to provide them with medical care."
Above is an explanation to support the facts given in answer B. Where as answer A provides only a tunnel approach and the answer is narrowed down to one particular aspect answer B has provided broader reasons. So answer B is selected.

question_text: If light has no mass, why does it bend in the presence of gravity?
answer1: Light doesn’t have mass in the conventional sense. Einstein theorized, essentially, that there can be no energy without mass. If E= 0, and c^2 is a constant, then m= 0. If m=0, then there is no energy. Light IS energy.<newline>So! Light ACTS like it has mass while in motion, and has no mass when at a halt. The answer you’re looking for is: 🤷‍♂️
answer2: Light travels in space. Gravity warps space, while light just keeps following wherever it goes. Although gravity doesn't affect photons, it does affect the surface upon which they move.
comments:
As answer "A" points out clearly, we consider light to be massless only in the classical world. But when it comes to Einstein's theory of relativity, he discusses about photons which comprises light and according to that theory, light is no longer treated to be massless. "According to Einstein's general theory of relativity, an object passing in front of another bright object would bend the light of the more distant object and cause it to appear to move from its original position", this is given in the website "https://www.abc.net.au/news/science/2017-06-08/einsteins-impossible-dream-comes true/8598552#:~:text=According%20to%20Einstein%27s%20general%20theory,move%20from%20its%20original%20position."
It further adds that "In this "gravitational lensing", the distance apparently travelled by the background object depends on the mass of the object in front, which is curving the light.
While gravitational lensing has been used by astronomers to study the galactic bulge in our Milky Way and other galaxies such as Andromeda and the Magellanic Clouds, this is the first time it has been used to study distant stars"  So overall we can consider answer A to provide a better explanation.
As per answer "B", the statement "Although gravity doesn't affect photons, it does affect the surface upon which they move." is questionable due to the fact that it is actually the photon that posses mass. So theoretically photons should be affected by gravity.
Answer A provides a better account of the question and seemingly it is a better answer than Answer B

question_text: Where do magnets get their energy to repel other magnets from? Does it last forever?
answer1: Magnetism is like gravity. Lift a ball off the ground, and you're putting in energy. Push two magnets together, and you're putting in energy. Let go, and the energy is released.<newline>Magnetism doesn't last forever, either. It's a result of the poles being aligned. Heat will shake them out of alignment.
answer2: A more poetic non-answer is: When I sing, where does the melody come from?
comments:
Answer B seems to be irrelevant in terms of the context.  When the two magnets are moved close to each other, there is energy associated. When the two magnets are moved close to each other, they repel as a result of magnetic repulsion due to magnetic poles being aligned. Furthermore, magnetism doesn't last forever. It actually diminishes. Magnetic properties of a magnetic material has the diminishing effect. Answer B lacks explanation with respect to the technical content.  
According to website "https://www.newscientist.com/lastword/mg24732911-800-does-magnetism-decay-over-time/#:~:text=At%20a%20temperature%20called%20the,cause%20magnetic%20properties%20to%20decay. " magnetism  has the effects of diminishing. "At a temperature called the Curie point – this varies in different metals, but it is around 770° in iron – permanent magnetism is lost altogether. Over a longer period of time, random temperature fluctuations, stray magnetic fields and mechanical movement will cause magnetic properties to decay." Answer B fails to give an explanation to this part of the question too.
Answer A brings the correct fact with respect to the destruction of magnetic force, "Magnetism doesn't last forever, either. It's a result of the poles being aligned. Heat will shake them out of alignment."

question_text: how can humans survive in the channel tunnel without a pressure suit? But no at that depth in sea? Is this down to the difference in density between air and water or is the air in the channel tunnel pressurised?
answer1: The tunnel is only full of air, so going that deep isn't as big of a deal. Water weighs A LOT more, so at that depth there is more weight crushing you.
answer2: Did a ctrl+f for pressure on the wikipedia page and found:<newline>> The ventilation system maintains the air pressure in the service tunnel higher than in the rail tunnels, so that in the event of a fire, smoke does not enter the service tunnel from the rail tunnels.<newline>So, yes there is a ventilation system that maintains the air pressure.<newline>> Trains travelling at high speed create piston effect pressure changes that can affect passenger comfort, ventilation systems, tunnel doors, fans and the structure of the trains, and which drag on the trains.[199] Piston relief ducts of 2-metre (7 ft) diameter were chosen to solve the problem, with 4 ducts per kilometre to give close to optimum results.<newline>I found this pretty interesting. They had to install vents because the trains running into the air was causing pressure problems.
comments:
According to answer "The tunnel is actually full of air, and it is breathable."  Although there is a pressurized ventilation system in the tunnel as per answer B, it is for the purpose of fire fighting. "The ventilation system maintains the air pressure in the service tunnel higher than in the rail tunnels, so that in the event of a fire, smoke does not enter the service tunnel from the rail tunnels. So, yes there is a ventilation system that maintains the air pressure". This is actually for the fire fighting. 
As correctly stated in Answer A", at sea level the water pressure is enormous due to high density, Because per unit volume, water weighs approximately 800 times greater than the air. Therefore, at that depth according to answer A, no human can survive unless protection measures are taken. This is correctly explained in answer A. "Water weighs A LOT more, so at that depth there is more weight crushing you"
Actually according to answer B, it is based on a false assumption that the ventilation system in fact for breathing. it is actually for the fire emergency. So overall answer A provides a better reasoning.

question_text: Since force is related to a change in momentum and not necessarily just to a change in velocity, what would be an example where only the mass of a body changes but not its velocity when subjected to a force?
answer1: Momentum is something that exists in mass. If you apply a force, it inherently *must* change an object's velocity (however slightly) and does not change its mass.<newline>To increase the momentum of an object, you must decrease the momentum of another object, as momentum is a conserved quantity. Note that momentum is a vector, and so a "decrease" could just as well mean an increase in the opposite direction. The force 'moves' momentum between the two objects.<newline>The force could, instead, move mass between the two objects, but the scenario is a bit odd, since the new mass isn't necessarily the same object but simply travels alongside the object.<newline>For example, imagine a very fast aircraft flying over enemy territory. So fast that it keeps pace with bullets. The enemy fires upon the aircraft, but the bullets can only match speeds with it and will not damage it. The bullets are now traveling with the aircraft, and with some mid-flight gluing they could become a part of it. In this case, the force of firing the bullet is pumping mass to the object without changing its velocity.
answer2: My first thought was particle accelerators where the particles are close to the universal speed limit and will therefore not go any faster no matter how much acceleration you give them but will instead increase in mass. However /u/LordSpazpatty is completely right with the hovering rocket example as well as the mass is reduced due to fuel being burned by the engines requiring less force to keep the same acceleration.
comments:
As per answer A application of force doesn't always necessarily change the velocity of an object. An example would be an object that is stationary on a rough surface would remain stationary until it is acted upon by an overwhelming force. Example given in answer A is a bit obscure also and comparatively in answer B the explanation of rocket seems to be assuming. In answer B the particle accelerator example in modern physics also a good explanation too. Answer B seems to be simple and straight forward in that sense.
Strictly speaking in terms of physics concepts, the force is the change in momentum per unit time. i.e rate of change in momentum. According to the Newton's second law, the force is equal to the rate of change of momentum. Usually, in classical mechanics, we consider the mass of an object to be constant. Therefore when a force is applied the rate of change of momentum occurs courtesy, the rate of change of velocity. In other words, when a force is applied, a particular object is subjected to acceleration or deceleration. But in certain cases, when the velocity is remained constant, the mass can vary. For an example, in an example of a rocket, due to fuel burn the mass decreases, but the velocity is held constant. This is in accordance with the second law of Newton. According to Answer B, "with the hovering rocket example as well as the mass is reduced due to fuel being burned by the engines requiring less force to keep the same acceleration". This may be the case in examples of moving bomber examples also. where the force applied is to maintain the speed of the bomber a constant despite the bombs dropped attributes to reduction of mass.
However in answer B "However /u/LordSpazpatty" is not clear. it must be a quote.
